accolade.example: Jean Paul-Sartre was not a fan of accolades, and as such, he refused to accept the Nobel Prize for Literature in 1964.
accolade.meaning: an award or praise granted as a special honor

admonish.example: Before the concert began, security personel admonished the crowd not to come up on stage during the performance.
admonish.meaning: to warn strongly, even to the point of reprimanding

antithetical.example: His deep emotional involvement with these ideas is, in fact, antithetical to the disattachment Buddhism preaches.
antithetical.meaning: sharply contrasted in character or purpose

arbitrary.example: One of the arbitrary decrees in place during the emperor's rule is that all citizens pay him weekly homage at his palace.
arbitrary.meaning: based on a random, groundless decision
arbitrary.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

arcane.example: Most college fraternities are known for arcane rituals that those hoping to the join the fraterntiy must learn.

audacity.example: She surprised her colleagues by having the audacity to publically criticize the findings of an distinguished scientist.

austere.example: His lifestyle of revelry and luxurious excess could hardly be called austere.
Late Soviet architecture, although remaining largely austere, moved into experimental territory that employed previously unused shapes and structures.
The principal of my elementary school was a cold, austere woman; I could never understand why she chose to work with children.

brazen.example: Their large "donations" to the local police department gave the drug cartel the brazen confidence to do their business out in the open.

circumscribe.example: Their tour of South America was circumscribed so that they saw only popular destinations and avoided the dangerous parts of cities.
circumscribe.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

constituent.example: The mayor's constituents are no longer happy with her performance and plan to vote for another candidate in the upcoming election.
constituent.meaning: a citizen who is represented in a government by officials for whom he or she votes

constituent.example: The constituents of the metal alloy are nickle, copper, and tin.

dilettante.example: to have knowledge Fred has no formal medical training; while he likes to claim authority on medical issues, he is little more than a dilettante
dilettante.meaning: an amateur who engages in an activity without serious intentions and who pretends

foment.example: After having his pay cut, Phil spread vicious rumors about his boss, hoping to foment a general feeling of discontent.
foment.meaning: try to stir up public opinion

garrulous.example: Lynne was garrulous: once, she had a fifteen minute conversation with a stranger before she realized the woman didn't speak English.

gauche.example: Sylvester says the most gauche things, such as telling a girl he liked that she was much prettier when she wore makeup.

haphazard.example: Many golf courses are designed with great care, but the greens on the county golf course seem entirely haphazard.
haphazard.meaning: marked by great carelessness; dependent upon or characterized by chance

hegemony.example: Until the Spanish Armada was defeated in 1587, Spain had hegemony over the seas, controlling waters stretching as far as the Americas.

inimical.example: Venus, with a surface temperature that would turn rubber to liquid, is inimical to any form of life.

inscrutable.example: His speech was so dense and confusing that many in the audience found it inscrutable.

insolent.example: Lilian could not help herself from being insolent, commenting that the Queen's shoes were showing too much toe.

intrepid.example: Captain Ahab was an intrepid captain whose reckless and fearless style ultimate leads to his downfall.

inveterate.example: He is an inveterate smoker and has told his family and friends that there is no way he will ever quit.

irrevocable.example: Once you enter your plea to the court, it is irrevocable so think carefully about what you will say.
irrevocable.meaning: incapable of being retracted or revoked

lionize.example: Students in the U.S. learn to lionize Jefferson, Franklin, and Washington because they are the founding fathers of the nation.

munificent.example: Uncle Charley was known for his munificence, giving all seven of his nephews lavish Christmas presents each year.

myriad.example: There are a myriad of internet sites hawking pills that claim to boost energy for hours on end.

obsequious.example: influential people by flattery The obsequious waiter did not give the couple a moment's peace all through the meal, constantly returning to their table to refill their water glasses and to tell them what a handsome pair they made.
obsequious.meaning: attentive in an ingratiating or servile manner; attempting to win favor from

ostracize.example: Later in his life, Leo Tolstoy was ostracized from the Russian Orthodox Church for his writings that contradicted church doctrine.
ostracize.meaning: exclude from a community or group

pedestrian.example: While Nan was always engaged in philosophical speculation, her brother was occupied with far more pedestrian concerns: how to earn a salary and run a household.
pedestrian.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

pernicious.example: The most successful viruses are pernicious: an infected person may feel perfectly healthy for several months while incubating and spreading the virus.
pernicious.meaning: exceedingly harmful; working or spreading in a hidden and injurious way

poignant.example: After the Montagues and Capulets discover the dead bodies of Romeo and Juliet, in the play's most poignant moment, the two griefstricken familes agree to end their feud once and for all.
poignant.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

precipitous.example: He was expecting a precipitous rise in the value of a "hot" tech stock, so he was disappointed when it only inched up a dollar or two each day.
precipitous.meaning: done with very great haste and without due deliberation

prodigious.example: After the relatively small homerun totals in the "dead ball" era, Babe Ruth's homerun totals were truly prodigious: every year, he set a new all-time record.
prodigious.meaning: so great in size or force or extent as to elicit awe

prolific.example: Schubert was the most prolific composer, producing hundreds of hours of music before he died at the age of 31.

propitious.example: The child's heartbeat is still weak, but I am seeing many propitious signs and I think that she may be healing.
propitious.meaning: presenting favorable circumstances; likely to result in or show signs of success

ravenous.example: John didn't each much at all during the week he had the flu, so now that he is regaining his health, it's not surpring that he has a ravenous appetite.
ravenous.meaning: extremely hungry; devouring or craving food in great quantities

repudiate.example: Many in the public believed the rumors of a UFO crash outside town, so the chief of police did everything he could to repudiate the rumors.

rescind.example: The man's driver's license was rescinded after his tenth car accident, which meant he would never be allowed to legally drive again.

resurgent.example: The team sank to fourth place in June, but is now resurgent and about to win the division.
resurgent.meaning: rising again as to new life and vigor

reverent.example: The professor could speak objectively about the other composers, but he always lectured about Brahms with a particularly reverent air, unable to offer a single criticism of his compositions.
reverent.meaning: feeling or showing profound respect or veneration

sanction.example: The authorities have sanctioned the use of the wilderness reserve for public use; many expect to see hikers an campers enjoying the park in the coming months.
International sanctions have been placed on certain shipping lanes that were thought to be involved in human trafficking.
sanction.meaning: a legal penalty for a forbidden action

scrupulous.example: Because of his scrupulous nature, Mary put him in charge of numbering and cataloging the entire collection of rare stamps.
scrupulous.meaning: characterized by extreme care and great effort

scrupulous.example: Everyone trusted what he said and followed his example because he was scrupulous and honest.
scrupulous.meaning: having a sense of right and wrong; principled

sporadic.example: The signals were at first sporadic, but now we detect a clear, consistent pattern of electromagnetic radiation eminating from deep space.
sporadic.meaning: recurring in scattered and irregular or unpredictable instances

subversive.example: The ruling political party has begun a campaign to shut down subversive websites that it deems as a threat to "national safety."
subversive.meaning: in opposition to a civil authority or government

sycophant.example: The CEO was unaware of the damaging consequences of his choices, largely because he surrounded himself with sycophants who would never dare criticize him.
sycophant.meaning: a person who tries to please someone in order to gain a personal advantage

taciturn.example: While the CEO enthusiastically shares his plans and agenda with all who will listen, the CFO is far more taciturn, rarely revealing his perspective.

tempered.example: The wide-eyed optimism of her youth was now tempered after she had worked many years in the criminal justice system.

tractable.example: taught or molded) Compared to middle school students, who have an untamed wildness about them, high school students are somewhat more tractable.
tractable.meaning: readily reacting to suggestions and influences; easily managed (controlled or

trite.example: Many style guides recommend not using idioms in writing because these trite expressions are uninteresting and show a lack of imagination on the part of the writer.
trite.meaning: repeated too often; overfamiliar through overuse

vacillate.example: action Some students vacillate between schools when deciding which to attend, while others focus only on one school.
vacillate.meaning: be undecided about something; waver between conflicting positions or courses of
vacillate.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE
